title: Road works and closures by local authority

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I would like to request the following information for the last calendar year (1 January 2024 to 31 December 2024):
1. The total number of road works carried out within your council locality. This refers only to road works undertaken by the authority or its contractors on behalf of the council. It does not include street works undertaken by utility companies, their contractors, or private developers.
2. The total number of road closures due to road works within your council locality. This includes full road closures, partial road closures, and nighttime closures.
3. The duration of each road work project carried out within your council locality.
If available, please provide:
Start date
End date (or indicate if still ongoing)
If the project lasted less than a day, please provide the duration in hours where possible.
4. The duration of each road closure due to road works within your council locality.
If available, please provide:
Start date
End date (or indicate if still ongoing)
If the closure lasted less than a day, please provide the length in hours where possible.
If this request exceeds the cost limit under the FOI Act, please advise how it may be refined to remain within statutory limits.
Thank you for your help. Please let me know if you require any clarification.
Yours faithfully,
Jamie Dixon

Dear Jamie Dixon,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Road works and

This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for

Before we can begin to process your FOI Request, we would like to clarify
what information you require.
We like you to clarify what you mean by “roadworks”. Our contractor Amey
has pointed out that Roadworks could include many different  workstreams
associated with closing roads and using temporary traffic management, such
as Local Implementation Plan, Highways, Drainage, Emergency works, Non
Core activity, lighting/traffic signals, and more.
Just looking at potholes, identifying the traffic management used as part
of the repair may prove difficult without reviewing every single job but
if we can get a steer for what to look at for Q1, we can review what is
needed for the other questions.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to a
request within 20 working days. The 20 working day clock will start the
day after we receive the necessary clarification.
You can provide your clarification by replying to this email. Please
note, if clarification is not received within 2 months your Freedom of
Information request will be closed.
We look forward to hearing from you.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Jamie Dixon
Thank you for your request for information relating to Road works and
closures by local authority, which we received on 11/03/2025.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. The total number of road works carried out within your council
locality. This refers only to road works undertaken by the authority or
its contractors on behalf of the council. It does not include street works
undertaken by utility companies, their contractors, or private developers.
8040 permits were approved for Amey works between 1^st January 2024 to
31^st December 2024.
Please note that in some instances, works may not have taken place.
We are withholding this information under Regulation 12(4)(b) of the
Environmental Information Regulations 2004 on the grounds that it would be
manifestly unreasonable to comply with the request. We do not record this
information in a format that allows us to produce an electronic report of
this and therefore, we would have to carry out a manual search of each
record. It is estimated that checking would take approximately two (2)
minutes per permit which would total approximately 268 hours.
Regulation 12(4)(b) is subject to a public interest test. Factors in
favour of disclosure are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it
is not in the public interest to spend such a large amount of officer time
on providing this information, as this would come at a large cost to the
council and would divert officers from being able to carry out other work.
On balance, the council believes that the public interest lies in
maintaining the exception.
2. The total number of road closures due to road works within your council
locality. This includes full road closures, partial road closures, and
nighttime closures.
1508 permits were approved which required some form of highway closure.
These included footway and carriageway works.
Please note that in some instances, works may not have taken place.  This
information is not in a readily searchable format.  To calculate the
actual number of road works, each permit would have to be checked
manually.  It is estimated that checking would take approximately two (2)
minutes per permit which would total approximately 50 hours.  We consider
this to be manifestly unreasonable.
3. The duration of each road work project carried out within your council
locality.
If available, please provide:
Start date
End date (or indicate if still ongoing)
If the project lasted less than a day, please provide the duration in
hours where possible.
See attached data titled ‘FOI 1805584 – Data’ under tab Q3. Total Permits.
Information regarding exact working time on site is not in a readily
searchable format.  To calculate the actual period, each permit and
associated jobs would have to be checked manually.  It is estimated that
checking would take approximately five (5) minutes per permit which would
total approximately 670 hours.  We consider this to be manifestly
unreasonable as with the exception quoted in the answer to Q1.
Where the permit start and end dates are the same, that is, all the works
are completed within the same day, we have assumed 5 hours as an average
timescale for the duration of the works.
4. The duration of each road closure due to road works within your council
locality.
If available, please provide:
Start date
End date (or indicate if still ongoing)
If the closure lasted less than a day, please provide the length in hours
where possible.
See attached data titled ‘FOI 1805584 – Data’ under tab Q4. Road Closures.
Information regarding road closure time is not in a readily searchable
format.  To calculate the actual period, each permit and associated jobs
would have to be checked manually.  It is estimated that checking would
take approximately five (5) minutes per permit which would total
approximately 125 hours.  We consider this to be manifestly unreasonable
as with the exception quoted in the answer to Q1.
Where the permit start and end dates are the same, that is, all the works
are completed within the same day, we have assumed 5 hours as an average
timescale for the road closure.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind regards
